unnormalised: ## Return Policies: Because Even Goddess Lakshmi Makes Mistakes (Sometimes)
normalised: ## Return Policies: Because Even Goddess Lakshmi Makes Mistakes (Sometimes)

unnormalised: Let's face it, buying stuff online or even from your friendly neighborhood Kirana store can be a gamble. Sometimes, that stunning silk saree you saw on Myntra looks more like something your grandmother would wear for puja, or the pressure cooker from Flipkart decides to explode at exactly 09:00 hrs on a Sunday morning. That, my friends, is where the humble (but oh-so-important) return policy comes in.
normalised: Let's face it, buying stuff online or even from your friendly neighborhood Kirana store can be a gamble. Sometimes, that stunning silk saree you saw on Myntra looks more like something your grandmother would wear for puja, or the pressure cooker from Flipkart decides to explode at exactly nine hours on a Sunday morning. That, my friends, is where the humble (but oh-so-important) return policy comes in.

unnormalised: Think of it as a "get out of jail free" card for bad shopping decisions. A safety net for when your "retail therapy" turns into "retail regret." Imagine ordering that "designer" kurta for your cousin Priya's wedding, only to discover it's made of material that feels suspiciously like sandpaper. Thank goodness for the return policy! You can pack that sartorial disaster back up faster than you can say "Paneer Tikka" and get your precious Rs. back.

unnormalised: But navigating return policies can be trickier than dodging traffic on Linking Road during rush hour. Some are as simple as ordering a jalebi, enjoying it, and then realizing you're lactose intolerant. "No problem!" says the return policy (metaphorically, of course, you can't return half-eaten jalebis, don't even try). Others… well, others are like trying to understand rocket science after one too many lassis.

unnormalised: Did you know, according to a survey conducted on 26/01/2023, 68% of Indians check the return policy *before* even considering buying something online? Smart folks!

unnormalised: Remember that time uncle Sharma bought a "genuine leather" wallet from a street vendor in Chandni Chowk on 15/08/1947 (just kidding, he’s not *that* old! Maybe 2015)? It turned out to be pleather that disintegrated faster than a politician's promise. No return policy there! Poor Sharmaji was left clutching a handful of plastic flakes and a bruised ego.

unnormalised: So, read the fine print, my friends! Know your rights. And if that pressure cooker DOES explode, make sure you document everything before contacting the company. You never know, you might just get a replacement... or at least enough coupons to buy a lifetime supply of Band-Aid.
